title: 111_hr5821
content: The Act is titled the "10 Million Solar Roofs Act of 2010" and includes definitions for various terms. The "10 Million Solar Roofs Act of 2010" defines terms such as eligible participant, Indian tribe, installed nameplate capacity, and local educational agency. Eligible participants include homeowners, business entities, local educational agencies, and other entities approved by the Secretary. Indian tribe is defined as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. Installed nameplate capacity refers to the maximum output of a solar electric system under specific conditions. Local educational agency is defined as per section 9101 of the Act. The "10 Million Solar Roofs Act of 2010" defines terms like agency, Secretary, and solar energy system with specific criteria for rooftop or ground-mounted solar equipment. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of Energy, and a solar energy system must have an installed capacity not exceeding 1 megawatt. SEC. 3. REBATES, LOANS, AND OTHER INCENTIVES FOR PURCHASE AND INSTALLATION OF SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEMS. The Secretary will establish a program to provide competitive grants for the purchase and installation of solar energy systems in the United States by States, Indian tribes, and local governments. Grants will be awarded based on specific criteria. The Secretary will establish a program to provide competitive grants for the purchase and installation of solar energy systems in the United States by States, Indian tribes, and local governments. Grants will be awarded based on specific criteria, including maximizing federal funds leverage, deploying solar energy, ensuring diversity in recipients, allocating funds to Indian tribes, and giving preference to recipients with distributed generation standards. The program provides competitive grants for solar energy systems to States, Indian tribes, and local governments. Grants are awarded based on specific criteria, including maximizing federal funds leverage, deploying solar energy, ensuring diversity in recipients, allocating funds to Indian tribes, and giving preference to recipients with distributed generation standards. The grants can be used to establish or expand solar rebate, loan, performance-based incentive, or innovative financing programs. For each fiscal year, grant recipients must certify to the Secretary that funds will be used to supplement, expand, or create new solar energy programs without supplanting existing ones, and to deploy more solar energy systems. Recipients also need to submit an implementation plan with projections for solar energy system deployment and data on eligible participants assisted. The Secretary may specify the type and capacity of solar energy systems for grant awards, with recipients responsible for a 20% non-federal share of funds received. The Department of Energy can use up to 5% of funds for administrative expenses, including monitoring and evaluation. Grant recipients can also use funds for administrative expenses. Eligible participants cannot receive rebates under both this Act and the Energy Policy Act of 2005. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 allows for coordination and consultation with grant recipients to ensure program alignment. The maximum incentive for rebates, grants, and tax credits cannot exceed 50% of the solar energy system's cost to the purchaser. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 allows for coordination and consultation with grant recipients to ensure program alignment. The Act aims to install distributed solar energy systems on 10,000,000 properties in the US by December 31, 2021. The Secretary must submit a report with recommendations to achieve this goal within 270 days of the Act's enactment. Authorization of Appropriations: The Secretary is authorized to receive funds for the program, with $250,000,000 allocated for fiscal year 2012 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2013 through 2021.
